body.p: Bile is a yellow-brown or yellow-green alkaline solution (pH 7.6 to 8.6) that contains mainly water, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids (such as lecithin), electrolytes, cholesterol, and triglycerides. The only components involved in digestion are bile salts and phospholipids. Bile salts and phospholipids are both amphipathic molecules with both a hydrophilic region and a hydrophobic region. Bile salts are produced from cholesterol and contain many of the same ring structures.

Bile salts and the phospholipid lecithin convert large lipid globules into small lipid globules in a process called emulsification [definition: emulsification - the breakdown of large globules of hydrocarbons, fats or lipids into smaller, uniformly distributed particles]. The non polar regions of bile salts and lecithin are attracted to the lipids via the hydrophobic effect and polar regions are left exposed to the digestive juices. The mechanical mixing in the intestines causes the large fat droplets to break into smaller fat droplets. Without the bile salts and lecithin, the small droplets would re-form big fat droplets, but the hydrophilic coating keeps the droplets broken up. We can observe the process of emulsificationby mixing dish detergent with fat reside, the detergent breaks down large droplets of oil and solubilizes the oil inwater.

The smaller lipid globules then present a large surface area for the actions of pancreatic lipase, which digest triglycerides. Bile salts are also involved in the absorption of digested lipids. In contrast to the many constituents of bile that are eliminated in feces, bile salts are reclaimed by a recycling mechanism. The liver then secretes them again in newly created bile.
